titleStmt.title: Larvae of the South Atlantic coral Favia gravida are tolerant to salinity and nutrient concentrations associated with river discharges

analytic.title: Larvae of the South Atlantic coral Favia gravida are tolerant to salinity and nutrient concentrations associated with river discharges

biblStruct.note: Received 28 April 2020; Received in revised form 24 July 2020; Accepted 12 August 2020

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Energy metabolism Nearshore reef Pollution Reef-building Settlement Stress-tolerant

abstract.p: Rivers release freshwater, nutrients and pollutants into reefs. This type of environmental stress reduces coral larvae settlement and alter its energy metabolism. We investigated the tolerance of Favia gravida (Scleractinia) larvae to river discharges. We exposed larvae to (i) different salinities (25, 30, 35 and 40 PSU); and (ii) dilutions of river water containing nutrients and metals (0, 20, 40, 60, 80 and 100% river water) under control salinity of 35 PSU. We then examined settlement and larval enzymatic activity. No differences in settlement were detected among salinities. Settlement was also similar to control for larvae under 100% river water. Enzymatic activity for citrate synthase remained unaltered for all treatments. Lactate dehydrogenase activity was slightly altered under different salinities, suggesting a mild stress response. Findings suggest that F. gravida larvae are tolerant to a wide range of salinity and nutrient conditions and that this is a stress-tolerant species.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Although reef-building corals are usually intolerant to salinity variations (Sheppard et al., 2018), there are many coral reefs that develop under the constant or seasonal influence of river discharges (Wolanski et al., 1984;Moberg et al., 1997;West and van Woesik, 2001). Besides freshwater, rivers are also the main source of nutrients, sediments and pollutants for coastal reefs (van Dam et al., 2011). Together, these elements produce a variety of potentially adverse effects on coral communities, including impaired photosynthetic activity, macroalgal growth, siltation and smothering, and metal contamination (Holthus et al., 1989;Telesnicki and Goldberg, 1995;Fabricius and Wolanski, 2000;Ramos et al., 2004;Fabricius, 2005;De'ath and Fabricius, 2010). Few adaptations against the influence of freshwater and suspended particles have been reported for reef-building corals, mainly associated with sediment-cleaning and increased heterotrophic feeding (Riegl, 1995;Mies et al., 2018). As a consequence, nearshore and naturally turbid reefs tend to display lower coral cover and diversity than offshore reefs, with communities comprised of fast-growing and stress-tolerant species (Kleypas, 1996;Anthony, 2006;Golbuu et al., 2011;Cacciapaglia and van Woesik, 2016).

River discharges are also reported to affect the early developmental stages of both nearshore and offshore coral populations. Their main effects include reduced gametogenesis and fecundity, and lower larval survival and settlement rates, all of which are mostly caused by nutrient enrichment, reduced salinity and increased sediment load (Tomascik and Sander, 1987;Edmunds and Davies, 1989;Wittenberg and Hunte, 1992;Gilmour, 1999;Gleason and Hoffman, 2011). River discharges also affect the larval metabolism because of the additional energy required to recover and maintain homeostasis (Sokolova et al., 2012;Sokolova, 2013).

Although not yet addressed specifically for the stress induced by river discharges, there are several different metabolic changes in coral larvae caused by environmental stress. These include variations in oxygen consumption, expression of antioxidant enzymes, and calcification rates (Rodriguez-Lanetty et al., 2009;Nakamura et al., 2011;Rivest and Hofmann, 2014).

Energy metabolism enzymes (anaerobic and aerobic pathways) are also important tools for assessing environmental stress tolerance in aquatic invertebrates, especially when multiple factors are acting in tandem (Pörtner, 2012;Sokolova et al., 2012;Sokolova, 2013). During glycolysis, glucose is converted to pyruvate. Under anaerobic conditions, pyruvate is reduced to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). This reaction recycles coenzymes necessary for glycolysis to continue, thus LDH is a diagnostic enzyme for the anaerobic pathways (Nelson and Cox, 2017). Under aerobic conditions, pyruvate is oxidized to acetyl coenzyme A (acetyl-CoA) within the mitochondria. Citrate synthase (CS) catalyzes the condensation of acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate into citrate, the first step of the citric acid cycle and highly exergonic reaction (Nelson and Cox, 2017). Although less productive, energy supplied by anaerobiosis is faster than aerobiosis (Voet et al., 2016). Therefore, anaerobiosis is important for organisms with low metabolism and this process can increase under environmental stress (Elumalai et al., 2007;Pörtner, 2012;Sokolova et al., 2012;Murphy and Richmond, 2016). As a consequence, LDH and CS have been confirmed as stress markers for reef-building corals (see Gattuso et al., 1993;Rivest and Hofmann, 2014;Fonseca et al., 2019).

While larval tolerance to stressors associated with river discharges has been investigated for several coral species in the Caribbean and Indo-Pacific, it remains unaddressed for South Atlantic species and from a metabolic perspective. South Atlantic reefs are highly endemic and mostly restricted to the Brazilian coast, extending for nearly 3000 km (Castro and Pires, 2001;Leão et al., 2016;Pereira-Filho et al., 2019). These reefs present lower coral cover (≈20% - Segal and Castro, 2011;Castro et al., 2012), but have recently received attention for being considered more resilient than Indo-Pacific and Caribbean reefs (Mies et al., 2020). South Atlantic coral populations are mostly comprised of massive and brooding species in both nearshore and offshore environments (Leão et al., 2003;Pires et al., 2016). Reefs in this region are also Fig. 1. The scleractinian coral Favia gravida (A) and its distribution range (area marked in red) in the Southern Atlantic Ocean (B), and Buranhém River water collection sites (red circles) and Favia gravida broodstock colonies collection site (white circle) at the Recife de Fora Marine Protected Area (dashed square) (C). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.) under the influence of discharges from several large rivers and are thus naturally exposed to high nutrient levels (Costa et al., 2006;Dutra et al., 2006;Segal and Castro, 2011;Castro et al., 2012). The nearshore reefs often present higher nitrogen content (>5 mg L − 1 ) and metal concentrations (typically ranging between 2 and μg L − 1 ) (Abrantes, 2018;Marques et al., 2019;Mies et al., 2020). Salinity may also vary in approximately 2-3 PSU (Abrantes, 2018;Omachi et al., 2019). Therefore, South Atlantic reefs are formed under conditions typically adverse for Indo-Pacific and Caribbean corals (Laborel, 1970;Leão et al., 2003;Mies et al., 2020).

To investigate the tolerance of South Atlantic coral larvae to river discharges, we selected the scleractinian species Favia gravida as a model (Fig. 1). This species is abundant and widely-distributed in multiple reef environments across a wide latitudinal range (Leão et al., 2003(Leão et al., , 2016. It is usually found in tidal pools and in shallow well-lit tops of both nearshore and offshore reefs in Brazil, West Africa, and several South Atlantic oceanic islands (Hetzel and Castro, 1994;Nunes et al., 2011;Hoeksema, 2012). In addition, this species occurs nearby rivers, with population size increasing in a gradient towards reefs and away from the rivers (Pereira et al., submitted). Favia gravida is also a stress-tolerant, robust, and highly-fecund hermaphroditic brooder that releases larvae during all four seasons, which makes its induced spawning and laboratory culture easier (Pires et al., 2016). Therefore, we addressed two hypotheses: salinity and nutrient concentrations associated with river discharge (i) reduce F. gravida larval settlement rates, and (ii) alter its larval energy metabolism.

div.head: Materials and methods
div.p: To assess how salinity and nutrients associated with river discharge influence F. gravida settlement and energy metabolism, we subjected its planula larvae to different salinities and river water dilutions (that were adjusted to control salinity). Energy metabolism was assessed through LDH and CS activity, which are stress markers associated with anaerobiosis and aerobiosis, respectively.

div.head: River water collection and analyses
div.p: Water for the experiments was collected at the Buranhém River (Porto Seguro, Bahia State, Brazil). This river discharges on several nearby reef communities and imprints a marked gradient of terrestrial influence. Nutrient, metal, and sterol concentrations are higher closer to the shore and become more diluted away from the coast (Leite et al., 2018;Abrantes, 2018;Marques et al., 2019). River water was collected on March 2018 during low tide at three sites located 2.0, 3.3 and 4.5 km away and upstream from the river mouth (16 • 26 ′ 49.2 ′′ S, 39 • 03 ′ 39.1 ′′ W). Thirty 1.5 L polyethylene terephthalate (PET) bottles were used for water collection, 10 per site. Water samples were then kept cold on ice (4 • C) before transport to the laboratory, where they were filtered (250 μm) and frozen (− 20 • C).

Temperature, pH, dissolved oxygen, conductivity, and salinity were measured during collection at each of the three sites using a multiparameter meter (HI 9828, Hanna Instruments). In the laboratory, total nitrogen was measured according to semi-micro-Kjeldahl method (nitrogen organic, method #66; APHA, 1999) and total phosphorus was measured according to the ascorbic acid method (phosphorus, method #73; APHA, 1999). For organic carbon and metal analyses, collected water samples were placed in 15-mL Falcon tubes and divided in two groups: non-filtered and filtered (0.45 μm), which were acidified with HNO 3 (1% final concentration), kept in aluminum foil and frozen at − 20 • C. The non-filtered and filtered samples were used for total and dissolved content, respectively. The organic carbon concentration was determined in a Total Organic Carbon Analyzer (TOCV-CPH, Shimadzu). For metal (Fe, Cu, Cr, Cd, Pb, Mn, and As) concentrations, samples were desalted according to Nadella et al. (2009) and concentrations determined using a High-Resolution Continuum Source Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (HR-CS GF AAS, Analytic Jena).

div.head: Larval cultures and experimental setting
div.p: On August 2018, 80 F. gravida broodstock colonies (area of 13.37 ± 3.93 cm 2 ) were collected at the Recife de Fora Marine Protected Area (no-take zone at 16 • 24 ′ 37.3 ′′ S, 038 • 59 ′ 09.1 ′′ W), where temperature varies between 24 and 29 • C and salinity between 33 and 38 PSU (Abrantes, 2018;Marques et al., 2019); nitrate is typically 3.0 mg L − 1 and phosphate 0.2 mg L − 1 (Mies et al., 2020). Collection was authorized by the Porto Seguro Environment Secretary (SMMA/Porto Seguro permit 05/2018) and the Brazilian Environmental Agency (IBAMA/-SISBIO permit 61793-1). Colonies were transported to the laboratory and then kept in the dark for 24 h to induce planulae release according to the protocol in Calderon et al. (2000). Release took place overnight and larvae (2-3 mm in diameter) were collected with a glass pipette and then pooled into a single 1 L glass tank before distribution to experimental vessels.

The experimental setup ( Fig. 2) consisted of twenty-seven 500-mL rounded glass vessels kept under gentle aeration in three water baths (each containing nine vessels) of 100 L. Water baths were connected to a 75 L sump with a 500-W submersible heater set to 26 • C (Table S1). Lighting was provided by six 12-W lamps and four 20-W lamps (both of 6500 K and providing 114.6 ± 7.2 μmol photon m − 2 s − 1 ) kept 15 cm above the vessels, with photoperiod maintained at 12 h of light and 12 h of dark (Table S2). Water changes of 50% of the total volume were performed daily in each vessel. Temperature, salinity and irradiance were monitored daily using a digital thermometer (MT512e, FullGauge), an optical refractometer (VX100SG, Vodex) and a quantum sensor (MQ-200, Apogee), respectively.

Forty larvae (stocking density of 80 larvae L − 1 ) were placed in each vessel with a ceramic tile (4 × 4 cm) resting on the bottom as substrate for settlement. Previously, the tiles were conditioned by being kept in running seawater for three days. The 27 vessels (experimental units) were divided in nine treatments containing three replicates each. Four treatments consisted of different salinities; 25, 30, 35 and 40 PSU, which were produced by mixing deionized water and Coral Pro Red Sea Salt according to the manufacturer instructions. The other five treatments consisted of different volume proportions (dilutions) of river water (20%, 40%, 60%, 80% and 100%) in deionized water, with the salinity of every dilution adjusted to 35 PSU using Coral Pro Red Sea Salt. Equal volumes of water collected at each of the three river sites were mixed in the experimental vessels in order to produce a mean representation of the river water physicochemical parameters (see Table 1). Vessels at 35 PSU without river water were used as a control for all the other eight treatments. Therefore, the experimental concentration of dissolved nutrients and metals ranged from zero (control) to the quantities listed in Table 1 (100% river water treatment). A competence assay was not performed due to the lack of known settlement inducers for F. gravida larvae.

Favia gravida larvae settle in four days (Calderon et al., 2000), therefore experiments lasted for this period. Larval settlement was recorded by counting individuals settled on the ceramic tile under a stereo-microscope (S6 D, Leica). A sample of 20 unsettled larvae was collected from each vessel at the end of the experiment and stored at − 80 • C for the enzymatic assays. Because the planulae metabolism varies during larval ontogenetic development (Okubo et al., 2008;Graham et al., 2013), enzymatic analyzes were performed only at the end of the experiments.

div.head: Enzymatic assays
div.p: Enzymatic activity was determined based on Lallier and Walsh (1991) with some modifications. Each frozen larval sample was sonicated (70 kHz, Sonaer Ultrasonics) in homogenization buffer solution containing 50 mM imidazole (pH 7.8) (Sigma-Aldrich) and 0.1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (PMSF) (Sigma-Aldrich). The samples were centrifuged (10,000 RPM, 20 min, 4 • C) and the supernatant was used as an enzymatic source. Measurements were performed by spectroscopy (absorbance at 340 nm) with a microplate reader (ELx 808 Universal Microplate Reader, BioTeck).

The LDH assay was performed in a reaction solution containing 0.2 M imidazole (pH 8.0), 5 mM sodium pyruvate and 0.15 mM nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH) (Sigma-Aldrich). LDH activity was initiated by adding 20 μL of the homogenate in 330 μL of the reaction solution and monitored at 340 nm. The CS assay was performed in reaction solution containing 50 mM 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)-1-piperazineethanesulfonic acid (HEPES), 0.1 mM acetyl-CoA and 0.1 mM dithionitrobenzoic acid (DTNB) (Sigma-Aldrich). The background activity was monitored by adding 10 μL of the homogenate in 290 μL of the reaction solution. CS activity was initiated by adding 50 μL of 3.5 mM oxaloacetic acid (Sigma-Aldrich) (final concentration 0.5 mM) and monitored at 412 nm. The control activity (reaction solution without enzymatic source) was determined in the LDH and CS assays. Enzymatic activity was normalized by homogenate protein concentration using a commercial reagent kit based on the Bradford method (Bradford, 1976) (Bradford Reagent, Sigma-Aldrich). Final enzymatic activity was expressed as Fig. 2. Experimental design for F. gravida larvae submitted to different salinities (25-40 PSU) and different dilutions of river water containing nutrients and metal (0-100% river water, with salinity adjusted to 35 PSU for all dilutions). Gray circles represent experimental vessels used for the salinity experiment, while black circles indicate vessels used for the river water dilution experiment. The dashed circle in the center is the control for both experiments (optimum salinity of 35 PSU without any river water addition). Three replicates were used for each of the nine treatments. units (U) mg protein − 1 . Measurements of LDH and CS activity and protein concentration were technically replicated for each individual sample (n = 2) for double-checking.

div.head: Statistical analyses
div.p: All statistical analyses were performed using R 3.5.2 (R Core Team, 2018). Settlement was compared between treatments using a generalized linear model (GLM) with Poisson distribution. Enzymatic activities were compared between treatments using a GLM with Gaussian distribution. GLM analyses were followed by post-hoc multiple comparisons of means with one control group (step-down Dunnett test) ('multicomp' package). For post-hoc analyses, the salinity of 35 PSU (with deionized water only) was considered as the control group. The normalities of the residuals were verified using a Shapiro-Wilk test. Data are expressed as mean ± standard deviation.

div.head: Results
div.p: No significant differences were detected in larval settlement (≈20%) among the salinity treatments (Table 2, Fig. 3). Settlement was significantly different among river water treatments but the post-hoc test indicated that only the 20% river water treatment had lower settlement than the control treatment (Table 2, Fig. 3).

LDH activity was significantly different among salinity treatments (GLM ANOVA, F 3,8 = 16.259, P < 0.001) but not among river water proportion treatments (GLM ANOVA, F 5,12 = 2.387, P = 0.101; Fig. 4). The post-hoc test for salinity treatments indicated that the control (salinity of 35 PSU with deionized water) had the lowest LDH activity (Fig. 4). CS activity was not significantly different for either among salinities (GLM ANOVA, F 3,8 = 1.254, P = 0.353) or river water proportion treatments (GLM ANOVA, F 5,12 = 0.834, P = 0.550) (Fig. 5).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: South Atlantic corals are under the influence of the discharge of several large rivers (Costa et al., 2006;Dutra et al., 2006;Segal and Castro, 2011;Castro et al., 2012). However, the larval tolerance to these stressors remains unassessed. Therefore, we tested if lower salinities and higher nutrient concentrations associated with river water could (1) reduce F. gravida larvae settlement rates, and (2) alter its larval energy metabolism.

Our findings suggest that F. gravida larvae are remarkably tolerant and adapted to a wide salinity range. Settlement rates did not differ between salinities of 25, 30, 35 and 40 PSU and from the rates previously reported in Calderon et al. (2000). Although CS activity was not different among salinities, LDH activity increased in all salinities when compared to the control. This increase in LDH activity in higher and lower salinities is possibly a compensatory response to moderate stress. This occurs because stress often produces an increase in anaerobiosis in order to repair damage and compensate for additional physiological and biochemical activity (Elumalai et al., 2007;Pörtner, 2012;Sokolova et al., 2012;Sokolova, 2013). Regardless of this stress response, our results suggest that F. gravida is able to recruit in low salinity levels that are often found near estuaries. This degree of tolerance to low salinity is unusual and unlike the case for several other scleractinian larvae, such as that of Orbicella faveolata, Platygyra daedalea, Acropora millepora, A. cytherea, and A. pulchra, all of which have been reported as sensitive to decreased salinity (Vermeij et al., 2006;Scott et al., 2013;Hédouin et al., 2015;Woods et al., 2016). An exception with behavior similar to F. gravida is Platygyra acuta, an Indo-Pacific species also often found in marginal conditions for reef development, whose larvae are able to settle at a salinity of 22 PSU (Chui and Ang., 2017). All those species, however, are broadcast spawners, which are typically less robust and resistant than larvae of brooding species such as F. gravida (Szmant-Froelich, 1984;Harrison and Wallace, 1990;Erdinger and Risk, 1995;Harrison, 2011).

div.head: Table 1
div.p: Physicochemical parameters (mean ± standard deviation for the three collection sites) of the Buranhém River water used for experiments on the effects of nutrients and metals on the settlement and energy metabolism of Favia gravida planula larvae. Data on the right column present mean nutrient and metal concentrations in each of the six river water dilutions (0, 20, 40, 60, 80 and 100% river watersee Materials and Methods). n/a not applicable. Nutrient enrichment has been often described as a factor that hinders larval development and settlement for Indo-Pacific and Caribbean corals, with few exceptions (Bassim and Sammarco, 2003;Loya et al., 2004;Lam et al., 2015;Humanes et al., 2016;Serrano et al., 2018). However, the planula larva of F. gravida seems to be particularly tolerant to nutrient enrichment. While Loya et al. (2004) describe that 0.01 mg L − 1 of phosphorus hinders larval development and survival for Stylophora pistillata, our experiments indicate that 0.07 mg L − 1 (100% river water, Table 1) does not affect the settlement of F. gravida. Stylophora pistillata larvae also presented reduced viability when exposed to approximately 0.05 mg L − 1 of nitrogen (Loya et al., 2004), while F. gravida larvae exposed to 0.1 mg L − 1 (100% river water) again Fig. 3. Settlement of Favia gravida planula larvae exposed to: (A) different salinities and (B) different volume proportions of river water containing nutrients and metals (refer to Table 1 for physicochemical parameters) adjusted to salinity of 35 PSU. Asterisks denote significant differences between control (salinity of 35 PSU with deionized water onlylight gray) and other treatments (dark gray) (P < 0.05). Error bars indicate standard deviation. Fig. 4. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) activity of Favia gravida larvae exposed to: (A) different salinities and (B) different volume proportions of river water containing nutrients and metals (refer to Table 1 for physicochemical parameters) adjusted to salinity of 35 PSU. Asterisks denote significant differences between control (salinity of 35 PSU with deionized water onlylight gray) and other treatments (dark gray) (P < 0.05). Error bars indicate standard deviation. Fig. 5. Citrate synthase (CS) activity of Favia gravida larvae exposed to: (A) different salinities and (B) different volume proportions of river water containing nutrients and metals (refer to Table 1 for physicochemical parameters) adjusted to salinity of 35 PSU. Asterisks denote significant differences between control (salinity of 35 PSU with deionized water onlylight gray) and other treatments (dark gray) (P < 0.05). Error bars indicate standard deviation.

developed and settled normally when compared to control conditions. In addition, both LDH and CS activities were not different between the control and the 100% river water treatment. Therefore, the response to nutrient enrichment seems species-specific.

It is unlikely that the dissolved metal content in the river water influenced our results. Although these compounds are responsible for several impacts on aquatic organisms, including oxidative stress, DNA damage, cell lysis and death (Kumar and Singh, 2010;Zhang and Reynolds, 2019), they were found in very low concentrations in the Buranhém River water. Dissolved copper usually triggers deleterious effects on coral larvae at values above 80 μg L − 1 (Reichelt-Brushett and Harrison, 2000;Negri and Hoogenboom, 2011;Kwok and Ang Jr, 2013;Woods et al., 2016), but the river water used contained only 0.22 μg L − 1 (Table 1). Lead induces larval mortality at 5.0 μg L − 1 (Woods et al., 2016) and dissolved cadmium reduces fertilization at 4.0 μg L − 1 (Reichelt-Brushett and Harrison, 2005); however, Buranhém River water contained 0.21 and 3.4 μg L − 1 , respectively (Table 1). We cannot exactly explain, however, why the 20% river water treatment, associated with lower nutrient and metal content, produced a lower larval settlement. Our best suggestion is that characteristics of this dilution may have caused such reduction, but this effect was later canceled by an increase in the concentration of the river water elements. However, it is important to stress that besides nutrients and metals, it is possible that other factors may have influenced these results, such as pesticides, biological toxins and other elements that may have been present in the Buranhém River water.

Our findings suggest that F. gravida larvae are tolerant to a wide range of salinity and nutrient concentrations that are found in both nearshore and offshore South Atlantic reefs (see Abrantes, 2018;Marques et al., 2019;Mies et al., 2020). These conditions produced only a mild change on its metabolism and may explain why F. gravida is often found in and adapted to nearshore reefs not far from river discharges. It is important to note, however, that these factors were tested independently and not in an interactive way. Together with F. gravida tolerance to high turbidity (Calderon et al., 2000;Ricardo et al., 2016) and its morphological plasticity (Amaral and Ramos, 2007;Hoeksema, 2012), these results explain why this species is adapted to environments located near river discharges. For example, F. gravida adults and recruits have been observed on reefs where salinity ranges from 30 to 38 (Abrantes, 2018). Compared to other scleractinians, it also displays a short (4-5 days) and lecithotrophic larval development (Calderon et al., 2000;Conceição et al., 2006), high recruitment and populational density (Abrantes, 2018), high growth rates (Oliveira, 2013), and early reproductive age (Conceição et al., 2006). Therefore, it is capable of rapidly colonizing disturbed environments, thus possibly being an opportunistic and stress-tolerant coral species.

Within the South Atlantic province (see Floeter et al., 2008), there are multiple reports of reef-building corals displaying adaptations to conditions considered adverse for reef formation elsewhere. For instance, many South Atlantic corals (including F. gravida) are generalist hosts, harboring multiple Symbiodiniaceae genera (Picciani et al., 2016;Teschima et al., 2019), which aids in the acclimation and adaptation to disturbances (Baker, 2003). Several species also display increased heterotrophic capacity to thrive under turbid and low irradiance conditions (Mies et al., 2018;Marangoni et al., 2019). This feature remains untested for F. gravida, but its relatively large corallites indicate that it may be an effective heterotroph (Anthony and Fabricius, 2000). In fact, turbid environments are major global warming refugia because the suspended sediment shade corals from high irradiance and increased sea surface temperature (van Woesik et al., 2012;Cacciapaglia and van Woesik, 2016;Morgan et al., 2017). Mussismilia braziliensis is an example of a resilient South Atlantic coral that thrives under turbid conditions and also increases its reproductive output in nutrient-enriched environments (Pires et al., 2011;Ribeiro et al., 2018). All these examples highlight and giver further support to the resilience of South Atlantic reef-building corals (see Mies et al., 2020). However, so far, F. gravida is the only coral among South Atlantic species that seems tolerant to both nutrient enrichment and significantly reduced salinity.

This work indicates that the scleractinian coral F. gravida, endemic to the South Atlantic, is a stress-tolerant species adapted to conditions associated with river discharges. In addition, it adds further support to the suggestion that the marginal South Atlantic reefs harbor multiple coral communities that may serve as refugia against both local and global disturbances (see Soares et al., 2017;Banha et al., 2019;Mies et al., 2020). Under the current scenario of increasing disturbances, including a potential global increase in river run-off (Piao et al., 2007), it is possible that F. gravida may become a more dominant species in the South Atlantic.
